page.title: 18The Chantries, Shalford Mill
page.content:
{Shalford Mill}was built around 1700. It is made of oak and chestnut and the roof tiles are hand made. Originally it was used to grind wheat, barley, oats and rye. It has not been used since 1918. In 1932 part of the mill was converted into a house which initially was used as a weekend residence by the family who owned it. During World War II evacuees were housed here. Since 1952 it has been a permanent residence. The mill is now owned by the National Trust.
{The Chantries}area is found on the North Downs, south of Guildford. In the Middle Ages a rich man, Mr. Norbridge sold the land he owned to a priest, on condition that he built a chantry chapel on it. This is where the community of the chapel sang daily masses for the souls of the founders.
